hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
gemma-3-27b-1temp-cli-manual-aistudio_tr: Puali'i grabbed the knife and went until he reached where Nāmakaokapāo'o was broiling his four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the children saw and ran to stand far away, frightened of Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: “Behold! Here is the knife in my hand, it is a thing to cut off your head today, and your head will be severed, then roasted with the sweet potato, and I will eat it first, and then it will be free (noa).” Nāmakaokapāo'o did not listen to these words of Puali'i, and then Puali'i spoke again, it was the second time. Puali'i prepared to cut Nāmakaokapāo'o with the knife, and at that moment Nāmakaokapāo'o recited his death chant for Puali'i. He chanted: “Beloved is the eye of my pāo'o (fish), O hapupu'u, O hāpāpa'a, may it be eaten or left, may Nākukui‘aimakaokalani leave it. Nākukui‘aimakaokalani is that one, he is my companion, Nāmakaokai‘a is the high chief of Hawai'i. Let it drift, let the spear drift aimlessly, a man with a spear, the spear with a shield, death to Nāmakaokapāo'o.”
gemma-3-27b-1temp-cli-manual-aistudio_co:
**Paragraph 7:**


• This paragraph marks a critical escalation in the conflict between Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o, culminating in a ritualized threat of violence and Nāmakaokapāo'o’s counter-ritual – a death chant. The imagery is steeped in symbolism relating to food, power, and the precariousness of life. The introduction of the ko‘ilipi (knife) is not merely a practical detail, but a symbolic instrument of power and potential sacrifice.

– The Knife (Ko‘ilipi): The ko‘ilipi is presented not just as a tool, but as a direct threat to Nāmakaokapāo'o’s life. Puali'i’s dramatic presentation of it – “Behold! Here is the knife in my hand…” – echoes the pronouncements of a kahuna (priest) delivering a judgment. The intention to sever the head and consume it with the sweet potato is a direct inversion of proper food offering protocols and a disturbing echo of human sacrifice practices from the 'Ai Kapu era. This suggests Puali'i is clinging to older, more brutal traditions.

– The Children’s Fear: The reaction of the children – fleeing in fear – highlights the gravity of the situation and the perceived danger of Puali'i. Their distance symbolizes the separation between the old ways (represented by Puali'i) and the future (potentially represented by Nāmakaokapāo'o). It also underscores the disruption of lokahi (harmony) within the community.

• Puali'i’s threat is framed as a conditional offering: he will consume Nāmakaokapāo'o after the sweet potato, and then it will be noa (free, purified). This is a twisted application of the concept of noa, usually achieved through proper ritual and offering to the gods. Here, Puali'i attempts to legitimize his violent intent through a perversion of religious practice. The phrase “noa” is used to signify the end of a taboo, but in this context, it’s a chilling declaration of finality.

• Nāmakaokapāo'o’s response is not one of fear or pleading, but of ritualized defiance. He doesn’t argue or attempt to reason with Puali'i; instead, he launches into a oli (chant), specifically a pule make (death chant). This is a crucial turning point.

– The Death Chant (Pule Make): The chant is complex and layered with symbolic meaning. The opening lines, “Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o,” are particularly significant. Aloha here isn’t necessarily a greeting of love, but a lament, a recognition of the preciousness of life, even as it is threatened. Maka (eye) is a recurring motif, linking back to Nāmakaokapāo'o’s name – Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (eyes of the pāo'o fish). This reinforces the idea that his identity is intrinsically tied to vision, perception, and perhaps, a connection to the ocean and its creatures. Pāo'o (pāo'o fish) – a deep-sea fish known for its large eyes – could also be a poetic reference to po'o (head), as suggested earlier.

– Nākukui‘aimakaokalani: The invocation of Nākukui‘aimakaokalani is the most enigmatic part of the chant. Nākukui – likely derived from kūki (to swell, to rise) and ‘ai (to eat, consume) – suggests a being associated with growth and sustenance. ‘Aimakaokalani – ‘ai (eat), maka (eye), oka (to consume), lani (heaven) – further reinforces this connection to nourishment and divine vision. This figure is presented as Nāmakaokapāo'o’s aikāne (companion, friend, lover), suggesting a powerful ally or spiritual protector. The plea for Nākukui‘aimakaokalani to “leave it” (let Puali'i’s threat pass) is a desperate attempt to invoke divine intervention.

– Nāmakaokai‘a: The final lines, identifying Nāmakaokai‘a as the high chief of Hawai'i, are a bold assertion of power and lineage. This is a direct challenge to Puali'i’s authority. Nāmakaokai‘a – nā (the), maka (eye), o (of), kai (sea), ‘a (and) – suggests a connection to the ocean and a lineage rooted in the sea. The repetition of “Let it drift, let the spear drift aimlessly” is a symbolic dismantling of Puali'i’s aggressive intent. The spear (ihe) and shield (pahu) represent traditional implements of warfare, but their aimless drifting suggests their powerlessness against Nāmakaokapāo'o’s spiritual defenses. The final declaration, “Death to Nāmakaokapāo'o,” is not a statement of fact, but a desperate wish, a curse uttered by Puali'i, countered by Nāmakaokapāo'o’s chant.

• The entire scene is a microcosm of the larger cultural conflict at play. Puali'i represents the remnants of the 'Ai Kapu system, clinging to power through intimidation and a distorted understanding of ritual. Nāmakaokapāo'o, through his defiance and his invocation of ancient chants, embodies a new, more resilient spirit, one that draws strength from the land, the sea, and the ancestors. The chant is not merely a defense; it is an assertion of identity and a declaration of sovereignty. The ambiguity of the chant’s outcome – will Nāmakaokapāo'o survive? – leaves the reader suspended in anticipation, poised for the next act of this unfolding drama.

reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
